content:
The Middle Class Tax Relief Act of 2006 includes tax relief for middle-class families such as credits, doubling the child tax credit, and eliminating the middle-class surcharge. Additionally, there is a surtax for families with incomes over $1 million. The Middle Class Tax Relief Act of 2006 offers a 10 percent tax reduction for the middle class, with an income limitation based on adjusted gross income. Additionally, there is a provision for a zero tax bracket for the poor. The Middle Class Tax Relief Act of 2006 provides a 10 percent tax reduction for the middle class based on adjusted gross income. It also includes a provision for a zero tax bracket for the poor, allowing a credit against the tax imposed for the taxable year. The Middle Class Tax Relief Act of 2006 offers a 10 percent tax reduction based on adjusted gross income. It includes a provision for a zero tax bracket for the poor, allowing a credit against the tax imposed for the taxable year. The legislation also specifies the calculation for the tax reduction based on income thresholds. SEC. 25E Middle class families tax relief credits effective for taxable years after enactment. SEC. 102 Double the child tax credit for middle class families. The child tax credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow a credit for each qualifying child of the taxpayer, consisting of a basic credit and an additional credit. The basic credit amount varies depending on the taxable year. The additional credit amount for the child tax credit is $1,000 before January 1, 2011, and $500 for other taxable years. There is a limitation on the additional credit based on adjusted gross income, with a reduction for taxpayers whose income exceeds $75,000 ($150,000 for joint returns). The child tax credit additional amount is $1,000 before January 1, 2011, and $500 for other years, with a limit based on adjusted gross income. Amendments to the tax code include changes to the basic credit determination and coordination with the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 103. ELIMINATE THE MIDDLE CLASS SURCHARGE. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to provide an exemption for individuals in 2007 from the alternative minimum tax if their adjusted gross income is below a certain threshold. For those with income above the threshold but below $112,500 ($225,000 for joint filers), a phased-in tax liability applies. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exempt individuals in 2007 from the alternative minimum tax if their adjusted gross income is below a certain threshold. The threshold amount is $100,000 ($200,000 for joint filers). The exemption does not apply to estates or trusts. The effective date for this amendment is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2005. TITLE II--SURTAX FOR FAMILIES WITH INCOMES OVER $1 MILLION

SEC. 201. SURTAX FOR FAMILIES WITH INCOMES OVER $1 MILLION.

    Amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to impose a surtax on taxpayers with adjusted gross incomes exceeding $500,000 ($1,000,000 for joint returns). The tax imposed will be increased based on specified tables for joint returns. For taxable income over $1,000,000 but not over $1,000,000,000, the tax is 7% of the excess over $1,000,000. For taxable income over $1,000,000,000, the tax is $69,930,000, plus 10% of the excess over $1,000,000,000. The tax rates for taxable income over $500,000 but not over $500,000,000 are 7% of the excess over $500,000. For taxable income over $500,000,000, the tax is $34,965,000, plus 10% of the excess over $500,000,000. This tax provision does not apply to estates and trusts. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. The provision shall not be considered a change in tax rate under section 15 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
